channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: From @WSJopinion: The Omicron variant is far less lethal than previous versions, and its fast spread may finally push us to herd immunity, writes Rob Arnott https://t.co/jhN9Ioy5UT

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer set a mid-January deadline for trying to change the chamber’s procedures on passing legislation if Republicans again block sweeping changes to the nation’s election laws https://t.co/pYzw9lO7TZ

Starbucks is requiring its U.S. employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 or submit to regular testing, one of the first large restaurant chains to take such a step ahead of potential federal vaccination mandates for large employers https://t.co/0NNFUGl64l
Apple became the first U.S. company to reach $3 trillion in market value, with shares tripling since the pandemic lows of March 2020 https://t.co/1ilbeCaH45

Three former Minneapolis police officers are set to go on trial for violating George Floyd’s civil rights. They can more easily lay the blame on Derek Chauvin, who won’t be tried with them, say lawyers not involved in the case. https://t.co/KIaLdEs478
Restaurants switched over to digital menus during the pandemic. Should we get rid of paper menus forever? Industry insiders weigh in. https://t.co/oK2nyFFdCR

Tesla has opened a new dealership in Xinjiang, the remote region where Chinese authorities are carrying out a campaign of forcible assimilation against religious minorities that has become a public-relations quagmire for Western brands https://t.co/83DUZxw6tq

Russia and Ukraine contest the legacy of Yaroslav the Wise, a figure whose remains Ukraine is now hunting for. Finding them would be a notable if symbolic victory at a moment of significant tension with its neighbor. https://t.co/RSZSQsRpEl

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday, the Pentagon said, becoming one of the highest-ranking officials in the Biden cabinet to contract the coronavirus https://t.co/NP3vFycQs9
The U.S. and Japan are staging joint exercises to prepare for regional conflict that could spill over from Chinese aggression https://t.co/JDO9pDPY2P
Some of the people who built the internet think it’s time for a reboot—starting with social media https://t.co/Uc1Peh4Hgz
A paper-packaging giant wants its customers to say goodbye to foam cups, clamshell containers and six-pack rings: “We are attacking anything that is plastic.” https://t.co/lO65cVm1C5
An overdose epidemic that has swept across North America is leading more cities to try to decriminalize small amounts of heroin, fentanyl, cocaine and other drugs https://t.co/wCe2GEKQNf
Hit TV shows typically get a hot start in cities, then spread to the rest of the country. “Yellowstone,” the most popular series on cable, bucked that pattern. https://t.co/EHelkijOZQ
Jelena McWilliams’s decision to resign as chairman of the FDIC paves the way for Democrats to gain control of the agency’s agenda https://t.co/373ZpTiICv
Many stock investors see increased threats to the pandemic-era rally as the Federal Reserve starts removing support for the economy https://t.co/zCcdzbKTVT
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/9FAutoUgHr https://t.co/rFFXNuDxWc
Tesla's annual vehicle deliveries surged 87% in 2021, growing at their fastest pace in years despite computer chip shortages https://t.co/tdDccsqX7L
Twitter has permanently suspended GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's personal account, citing violations of the platform’s Covid-19 misinformation policy https://t.co/eZAng8Ay8z
With Covid-19 infections surging due to the fast-spreading Omicron variant, doctors are now urging people to ditch cloth face masks https://t.co/Frp9vq4nEi
With Covid-19 infections surging due to the fast-spreading Omicron variant, doctors are now urging people to ditch cloth face masks https://t.co/dopTYDxqMv
“In a triangle with three countries, you don’t want to be the one opposite the other two.” Strengthened military ties between China and Russia are triggering U.S. concerns. https://t.co/v2OBXF4KIu

A couple bought their first home together in London and turned a stripped-down warehouse space into a cozy two-bedroom home built for their work-from-home lifestyle—all during the pandemic https://t.co/LDJztphsGV
“In a triangle with three countries, you don’t want to be the one opposite the other two.” Strengthened military ties between China and Russia are triggering U.S. concerns. https://t.co/pOS6eRgH8G
A paper-packaging giant wants its customers to say goodbye to foam cups, clamshell containers and six-pack rings: “We are attacking anything that is plastic.” https://t.co/kNtAs3QiSm

From @WSJopinion: China’s Communist Party views all economic activity as fundamentally political. This week’s crackdown illustrates how no one is safe doing business in Hong Kong. https://t.co/OqB2OMuf9n

From @WSJopinion: The 2022 Olympics have been scheduled under the orchestration of a genocidal regime, writes @iguangcheng. Can any self-respecting democratic nation agree to attend? https://t.co/L0iIL0hiij
Shortened quarantines pose a risk that some people will go on to spread Covid-19 after their isolation period expires, the WHO said https://t.co/ZbBc7WNE7O
Review: The "Harry Potter 20th Anniversary: Return to Hogwarts" reunion special lacks the magic that made the original stories so great https://t.co/KsI75GHhi1
The CDC raised its travel warning for cruise ships to its highest level, telling Americans to avoid cruises regardless of their Covid-19 vaccination status https://t.co/WcXz21AlmV

What’s it like to be a muggle named Hermione? The children of Harry Potter fans talk about having a name from the series. One girl’s grandfather had to find a trick to remember it: “Her. My. Knee.” https://t.co/WdbTr4bgKO

Tesla is recalling nearly half a million cars it has produced in recent years because of potential safety defects, federal regulators said, adding to previous recalls and other safety concerns that have hit the electric-vehicle maker this year https://t.co/6mRNtG8BGx
From Albus to Draco, Harry Potter fans named their children after characters of the beloved series. We asked them and their kids how that turned out. https://t.co/sJSwQSbqsx
Shares of SenseTime jumped in their Hong Kong debut, after the Chinese AI company completed a $744 million IPO that had been delayed by tensions between Washington and Beijing https://t.co/8H3vTq5tgW

The sex-trafficking conviction of British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell brings a measure of justice to the scores of women who accused disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein of sexual abuse, the accusers and their lawyers said https://t.co/ilsNrkhhPI
Former Facebook executives said that after the whistleblower's disclosures, CEO Mark Zuckerberg told employees not to apologize https://t.co/joBEYuq1gA
Many NYU graduate degrees don’t pay off. Comparing debt loads with early-career earnings, it ranked worst of any university in 15 graduate programs. https://t.co/SiH6FYhYyH

Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty on five of six criminal counts in her sex-trafficking case, including sex trafficking of minors, which carries a maximum sentence of 40 years in prison https://t.co/WjY4c8SJvH
A federal judge rejected Oklahoma’s attempt to halt a Covid-19 vaccine mandate for its National Guard members https://t.co/2dpJ3Vcdxi
From @WSJopinion: Biden’s presidency is not accomplishing much and maybe was never intended to, writes Holman Jenkins https://t.co/XYseBkQ3zN

“They have relocated musicians, soccer players and artists, and their lives were not at risk as much as ours.” Afghanistan’s former female troops, once hailed by the West, fear for their lives. https://t.co/VneqAnkIm3
Breaking: Ghislaine Maxwell, longtime confidante of Jeffrey Epstein, was found guilty of some sex-trafficking counts, capping a yearslong push to bring her to justice https://t.co/AIC07h192p

A Russian judge dissolved one of the country’s oldest and most prestigious organizations dedicated to human rights on Tuesday, a move that government critics say furthers President Vladimir Putin’s assault on dissent https://t.co/zcDARBI1Ag
From @WSJopinion: A 10-day treatment costs only $4 and appears to greatly reduce symptoms, hospitalization and death, writes Allysia Finley https://t.co/WlKISQDYfX
Produce, dairy and packaged food such as bread and juice are among many food items set to become more pricey next year https://t.co/BpBi9vgKkt
It’s not just the accent: Ted Lasso’s pop-culture references come so fast and furious that you’ve probably missed a lot. We’re here to help. https://t.co/tDsFw6xTjY
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/AUSGROYKD3

Football coach and commentator John Madden, who died Tuesday at age 85, made a complex sport sound like backyard fun. That’s a small part of Madden’s deep legacy, writes @JasonGay https://t.co/JXyMTddkvk
The arrests of seven people linked to a popular Hong Kong pro-democracy news site dealt a new blow to press freedom in the city https://t.co/vyvYp3OgXm
The mummy of the Egyptian pharoah Amenhotep I, who lived more than 3,500 years ago, has been “digitally unwrapped,” thanks to CT scans https://t.co/5Pk3urp1WU
